awd_titl_txt: Pyrrole-modified Porphyrins - Chromophores of Basic and Applied Interests
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor Brueckner, a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry at the University of Connecticut. Blood is red and grass is green because of a particular class of compounds - so called porphyrins, that fulfill diverse roles throughout the living world. In addition to these natural roles, these highly colored compounds can potentially be used for a variety of "non-natural" applications that range from their use as contrast agents to improve the imaging of biological tissue for better disease detection to their use for the electrocatalytic reduction of carbon dioxide and in chemosensing efforts. With this in mind, Professor Brueckner is developing strategies to convert naturally occurring porphyrins to derivatives that possess properties the original compounds do not have. This allows them to be optimized for new applications. In addition, the derivatives being synthesized are well-suited for answering fundamental questions about the properties of the porphyrins and how those properties can be systematically altered by changes in structure. The project teaches graduate and undergraduate students in the techniques and methodologies that are used in the pharmaceutical and other industries. In this way, students are prepared to enter the workplace. Professor Brueckner's has traditionally been active in chemical education and in attracting students underrepresented in science to this most colorful research work. The multidisciplinary and very visual nature of the research make it ideal for outreach activities.



The main objective of this proposal is the development of strategies to convert porphyrins into pyrrole-modified porphyrins (PMPs). PMPs are macrocycles derived from porphyrins by formally replacing at least one pyrrolic building block with a different heterocycle. Starting from synthetic porphyrins, a relatively little explored strategy will be pursued: activation of the beta-position of porphyrins, followed by ring cleavage and subsequent ring-fusion. Focus in this study is the generation of PMPs containing multiple modified pyrroles, medium-size rings, or multiple annulated ring systems. The guiding hypothesis is that these modifications result in altered electronic properties when compared to their parent compounds. The suitability of the PMPs in several biological (i.e., contrast agents in photoacoustic tissue imaging) and technical (i.e. electrocatalytic reduction of CO2, chemosensing) applications will be evaluated. The proposed work relies on collaborations with intramural and extramural (international) specialty groups in a number of biological, physical sciences and engineering disciplines. The program offers a multidisciplinary and collaborative training ground for graduate students in diverse areas ranging from organic and inorganic synthesis, physical organic chemistry, photophysics, to a number of biomedical and engineering applications. This prepares them for future careers in industry or academia. The proposal also includes year-round undergraduate research projects, and it will be part of the departmental REU program. The multidisciplinary porphyrin-related research activities are ideal for dissemination in non-technical journals and make colorful subjects of outreach activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Blood is red and leaves are green because of the presence of two related molecules: Porphyrins and chlorins (dihydroporphyrins). These compounds have also been referred to as the ‘pigments of life’. The protoporphyrin iron complex in blood, called heme, is crucial in binding and transporting oxygen in our body but is also used in many enzymes in, e.g., the liver. Algae and higher plants utilize the green magnesium complexes of chlorins, called chlorophylls, as light harvesting pigments. The energy of the light is used in photosynthesis, the light-driven generation of carbohydrates. Certain bacteria also perform photosynthesis, but they use the purple magnesium complexes of bacteriochlorins (tetrahydroporphyrins), the bacteriochlorophylls. These crucial functions of porphyrins and hydroporphyrins to sustain live made their study most attractive, not the least because of the desire to realize artificial light-harvesting systems. Furthermore, several other technical and biomedical applications were found for these molecules.

Despite the ubiquity of naturally occurring heme and chlorophylls, they are not very suitable for many of these applications. They are chemically fairly unstable – after all, a green leaf also turns yellow or brown as soon as the plant’s machinery to keep the chlorophyll stable is switched off by a cold snap or drought. Because of this, a range of methods toward synthetic chlorins were developed: One approach, for example, is the building of the chlorin or bacteriochlorin macrocycle from smaller building blocks. Another approach is the conversion of a simple, readily made synthetic porphyrin – think of either building a convertible from parts or by chopping off the roof of a sedan. 

Funding by the NSF allowed us the refinement of the latter strategy, i.e., the synthesis and study of hydroporphyrin analogues called pyrrole-modified porphyrins by conversion of a synthetic porphyrin. Some of the resulting compounds ‘look and feel’ like real chlorins and bacteriochlorins but some possess functionalities and properties that go beyond what can be found in naturally occurring systems. They have been studied to understand their fundamental properties. Thus, our work contributed to the general understanding of the rules governing the chemistry of porphyrins, chlorins, and bacteriochlorins. We also matched several applications to the properties of the pyrrole-modified porphyrins. 

One specific fundamental and one applied project highlight our approaches and achievements: 

(1) We converted a class of porphyrins to so-called porpholactones. This relatively easy done once on the molecule that offers four identical positions for this transformation; in fact, this reaction is well-known. But to do this twice on the same molecule generates five possible isomers, created by the many possible positions and orientations in which the functionalization can take place. Our work figured out the rules that determined the regiochemistry, we prepared and analyzed all isomers, and explained why all had different optical properties. Unprecedented, we pushed the transformation to take place trice on the same molecule. Common knowledge dictated that this could not be done without losing key properties of the molecules (the so-called aromaticity). Yet, we showed that the compounds remained to be aromatic and explained this with a new model of porphyrinoid aromaticity. Aromaticity is a property that rules the chemistry of many molecules used in pharmaceuticals, plastics, and paints, and any advance in the understanding of aromaticity is therefore of fundamental interest and importance.

(2) One more applied example relates to the development of catalysts that mediate the generation of hydrogen gas from water, a reaction of importance when converting renewable electrical energy to a non-carbon emitting fuel. The functionality we were able to establish on the periphery of the pyrrole-modified porphyrins was used to assist in the efficient generation of hydrogen, pointing toward general design principles for better catalysts.

The grant funding was also crucial in graduate and undergraduate student training in the synthesis and characterization of small molecules using many spectroscopic techniques. Much of the work required collaborations with other groups. The ability to manipulate molecules at specific positions, the capacity to using spectroscopic techniques to prove the structure of the new molecules, and the facility of working in collaborative environments are key skills needed in, e.g., the pharmaceutical industry (where most of our students end up). Some students also chose academic careers, educating now a new generation of scientists on their own. 

The funding also allowed us to reach out to high school students and members of the science-curious public to tell them about porphyrins and chlorins found in nature, or to introduce them to the wonderful world of scientific discovery, and how science makes our lives better, in general.
